title: 2014–15 Bundesliga
text:
The 2014–15 Bundesliga was the 52nd season of the <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a>, Germany's premier <a href="association%20football">football</a> competition. The season started on 22 August 2014 and the final matchday took place on 23 May 2015. <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a> won their 25th <a href="List%20of%20German%20football%20champions">German title</a> on 26 April 2015.
Background.
Bayern Munich came into the season as defending champions, winning the championship on 25 March 2014 against <a href="Hertha%20BSC">Hertha BSC</a>. <a href="Armin%20Veh">Armin Veh</a> announced that he was leaving <a href="Eintracht%20Frankfurt">Eintracht Frankfurt</a> during the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Eintracht%20Frankfurt%20season">2013–14 season</a>. He had demanded that the club invest more money in the squad. <a href="Thomas%20Schaaf">Thomas Schaaf</a> replaced Veh. <a href="Bayer%2004%20Leverkusen">Bayer Leverkusen</a> sacked <a href="Sami%20Hyypi%C3%A4">Sami Hyypiä</a> during the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Bayer%2004%20Leverkusen%20season">2013–14 season</a>. <a href="Sascha%20Lewandowski">Sascha Lewandowski</a> was named interim manager. Lewandowski's interim reign lasted until the end of the season when <a href="Roger%20Schmidt%20%28football%20manager%29">Roger Schmidt</a> took over. Other managerial changes include <a href="Kasper%20Hjulmand">Kasper Hjulmand</a> replacing <a href="Thomas%20Tuchel">Thomas Tuchel</a> at <a href="1.%20FSV%20Mainz%2005">1. FSV Mainz 05</a> and Armin Veh replacing <a href="Huub%20Stevens">Huub Stevens</a> at <a href="VfB%20Stuttgart">VfB Stuttgart</a>. Every club received their licence. The league schedule came out on 24 June with <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a> facing <a href="VfL%20Wolfsburg">VfL Wolfsburg</a> in the opening fixture on 22 August. The match ended 2–1 win for Bayern Munich, a record third straight win for the home team, on the opening matchday, in the last three seasons.
Teams.
18 teams comprise the league. 15 sides qualified directly from the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Bundesliga">2013–14 season</a> and two sides were directly promoted from the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%202.%20Bundesliga">2013–14 2. Fußball-Bundesliga season</a>: <a href="1.%20FC%20K%C3%B6ln">1. FC Köln</a> and <a href="SC%20Paderborn%2007">SC Paderborn 07</a>. The final participant was decided by a <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Bundesliga%23Relegation%20play-offs">two-legged play-off</a>, in which 16th-placed Bundesliga club <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a> defeated third-place finisher in <a href="2.%20Bundesliga">2. Bundesliga</a>, <a href="SpVgg%20Greuther%20F%C3%BCrth">SpVgg Greuther Fürth</a>.
Relegation play-offs.
The team which finishes 16th, will face the third-placed <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%202.%20Bundesliga">2014–15 2. Bundesliga</a> side for a two-legged play-off. The winner on <a href="Playoff%20format%23Total%20points%20series%20%28aggregate%29">aggregate</a> score after both matches earns entry into the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Bundesliga">2015–16 Bundesliga</a>. <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a> prevailed for the second year in a row, avoiding their possible first relegation.
Second leg.
"Hamburger SV won 3–2 on aggregate."
